p: EOs could be added to edible oils and fat to block unsaturated oilsâ€™ oxidative reaction, causing unpleasant taste and flavor production. The oxidation of fat could also produce some toxic compounds, such as aliphatic and aromatic ketones, carboxylic acids, aldehydes, esters, sulfoxides, phenols, anhydrides, quinones, and aliphatic and aromatic alcohols [ 243]. Adding oregano EO in a combination of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids inhibited the oxidation process in the presence of light for one year [ 244]. The same results were observed when blackseed EO ( Nigella sativa L.) was added to sunflower oil [ 203], clove and thyme EOs to cottonseed oil [ 245], and zenyan EO to mayonnaise [ 246].
